name: Two agent-based models of cooperation in dynamic groups and fixed social networks
description: Both models simulate n-person prisoner dilemma in groups (left figure) where agents decide to C/D – using a stochastic threshold algorithm with reinforcement learning components. We model fixed (*single group ABM*) and dynamic groups (*bad-barrels ABM*). The purpose of the *bad-barrels model* is to assess the impact of information during meritocratic matching. In the *bad-barrels model*, we incorporated a multidimensional structure in which agents are also embedded in a social network (2-person PD). We modeled a random and homophilous network via a random spatial graph algorithm (right figure).
referencePublication: de Matos Fernandes, C.A., Flache, A., Bakker, D.M., & Dijkstra, J. (2022). A Bad Barrel Spoils a Good Apple: How Uncertainty and Networks Affect Whether Matching Rules Can Foster Cooperation. *Journal of Artificial Societies and Social Simulation, 25*(1), 6. doi: 10.18564/jasss.4754
